Principal Investigators.Name: Kate Starbird
Principal Investigators.Bio: Kate combines computational methods and qualitiative methods to understand social phenomenon at scale. One major focus of her work examines the use of social media during crisis events, specifically looking at how the converging audience (aka, the "crowd") can contribute—and is already contributing—to crisis response efforts.

Principal Investigators.Name: Emma Spiro
Principal Investigators.Bio: Emma studies online communication and information-related behaviors in the context of emergencies and disaster events. Her work also explores the structure and dynamics of interpersonal and organizational networks in both online and offline environments.

Principal Investigators.Name: Robert Mason
Principal Investigators.Bio: Robert's current research interests focus on the philosophy and ethics of technology management and the cultural aspects of knowledge management. His recent research examines the impact of social media on knowledge work and how organizations provide post-implementation support for enterprise systems. He is a founding member of the Social Media Lab @ UW (somelab.net) and is working with a team of students on information flows related to the Occupy movement.

Graduate Students.Name: Ahmer Arif
Graduate Students.Bio: Ahmer is interested in studying how sharing and consuming information around crisis events on social media affects people on an emotional level. Ahmer really digs spending time with his wife, playing board-games and being a total foodie.

Graduate Students.Name: Elodie Fichet
Graduate Students.Bio: Elodie's research focuses on Crisis Communication and how the use of new technologies has affected crisis response from both the professional and public realms. She often takes a qualitative perspective on the lab's research streams. She has worked - and continues to work - on self-corrective behaviors on Twitter (in response to rumor propagation) as well as the impact of 'official accounts' on rumoring during crisis situations.

Graduate Students.Name: A. Conrad Nied
Graduate Students.Bio: Conrad is most excited about bringing more tools for interacting with the crisis data and using natural language processing to understands patterns in the data. Conrad is generally interested in personalized user feedback in CMC. Out of school, he likes to bake cookies, dance, and play with his cat Simba.

Graduate Students.Name: Paul Townsend
Graduate Students.Bio: Paul joined the team in late 2015 with an interest in the human experience of rumoring in social media.  In his current Master’s studies, he has a real passion for spotting and analyzing user needs and bringing clarity to design opportunities.  This has been true throughout his life, from an earlier career in mechanical engineering, to a brief venture custom designing woodwork, to current work defining and prioritizing business and UX enhancements in the wireless industry.

Graduate Students.Name: John Robinson
Graduate Students.Bio: John is interested in design considerations for emergency response technologies. He comes to his PhD studies with over 15 years of software development experience including the first internet-streaming consumer-electronics devices. John spends a lot of time thinking about information visualization, emergent intelligences, decision making, and virtual collaborations. In his spare time, he volunteers with various youth and outreach programs. He also enjoys films, games, and music.

Graduate Students.Name: Tom Wilson
Graduate Students.Bio: Tom is new grad student interested in the role of geography in rumoring behavior and more.

Graduate Students.Name: Li Zeng
Graduate Students.Bio: Li is interested in implementing data analytics to understand rumoring transmission behaviors and developing machine learning strategies to automatically identify rumors on social media. She is currently working on designing machine learning experiments to identify rumor-affirming tweets and rumor-denying tweets for the project.

Undergraduates.Name: Isabelle Edwards
Undergraduates.Bio: Isabelle is interested in a mixture of qualitative and quantitative analysis looking at the appearance of expressed uncertainty in times of crisis and how that might relate to rumoring behavior. Isabelle started working with this group in summer of 2015 and is an English and Informatics major interested in data science and media analysis. Outside of school Isabelle works as a Veterinary Assistant, writes short fiction and cuddles dogs whenever possible.

Undergraduates.Name: Zena Getachew
Undergraduates.Bio: Zena is interested in the relationship between society and technology, and more specifically unpacking the ways in which social media trends inform and reflect social and cultural elements. She enjoys reading, writing, and exploring hole in the ground restaurants. She (mistakenly) attributes her frequent—if not relentless—misuse of idioms to her being the daughter of Ethiopian immigrants.

Undergraduates.Name: Madison Holbrook
Undergraduates.Bio: Madison explores the relationship between human’s psychological processes, how the presence of social media affects their information, communication, development and involvement, and its occurrence/ amplification across multiple media platforms. Her goal is to understand these interactions and utilize social media and technology in a way that can solve world problems in more efficient ways.

Undergraduates.Name: Coulter L'Heureux
Undergraduates.Bio: Coulter joined in the Rumoring DRG in the summer of 2015.  He is currently developing a system that collects information about deleted tweets and is researching how these tweets relate to corrective behavior surrounding crisis events on Twitter.  In his spare time, Coulter enjoys golfing, video games, and spending time with friends and family.

Undergraduates.Name: Gina Lee
Undergraduates.Bio: Gina joined the rumoring DRG as a qualitative coder in Winter 2016. She is interested in how information, especially from social media, can be utilized to assist people in disasters and repairing infrastructure. Her goals are to connect people with information through technology and design.

Undergraduates.Name: Andrew Newton
Undergraduates.Bio: Andrew intends on pursuing a degree in HCDE. Taking HCDE core classes, he’s eager to apply the knowledge that he’s learning each day to helping our systems to be more autonomous. Andrew enjoys gaming, but off the computer he can often be found sailing, running, and practicing archery.

Undergraduates.Name: Stephanie Stanek
Undergraduates.Bio: Stephanie has been in the lab since Winter 2014. She really enjoys qualitatively coding tweets after we collect data from a crisis event on Twitter. She is also interested in corrective behavior on Twitter, such as how Tweeters choose to correct themselves after they discover they have shared false information during a crisis event.

Undergraduates.Name: Madeleine Stewart
Undergraduates.Bio: Madeleine is interested in the development of narratives on social media, especially in the context of protests and social movements.  Besides her current project, she’s passionate about how technology and big data can be used for social good.  In her free time, Madeleine enjoys distance running and exploring Seattle.

Undergraduates.Name: Logan Walls
Undergraduates.Bio: Logan is interested in quantitative methods for analyzing unstructured data, and the psychological/sociological implications of rumoring in the online space. He is currently working on a machine-learning based approach to scoping social-media data. Outside of school Logan gets excited about futurism, story-driven media, and philosophy.

Undergraduates.Name: Kaitlyn Zhou
Undergraduates.Bio: Kaitlyn has been working with this DRG since spring of 2015. Currently, she is involved in projects involving uncertainty in tweets and permutations in rumors.
